query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
1 ‘Per me si va ne la città dolente, 2 per me si va ne l’etterno dolore, 3 per me si va tra la perduta gente.
query.result:
**English:**
1 Through me one goes to the city of woe, 2 through me one goes to eternal sorrow, 3 through me one goes among the lost people.
**Old English:**
1 Þurh me mon gæð on ða wæpnedceaster, 2 þurh me mon gæð on ðone ecan witu, 3 þurh me mon gæð on ða forlorenan leoda.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
4 Giustizia mosse il mio alto fattore; 5 fecemi la divina podestate, 6 la somma sapïenza e ’l primo amore.
query.result:
**English:**
4 Justice moved my exalted Maker; 5 divine power made me, 6 supreme wisdom and primal love.
**Old English:**
4 Rihtwisnes astyrede minne heahn Frea; 5 geworhte me ða wuldres Waldend, 6 ðæs hehstan heahfæderas wisdom and ðæs mæran lufe.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
7 Dinanzi a me non fuor cose create 8 se non etterne, e io etterno duro. 9 Lasciate ogne speranza, voi ch’intrate’.
query.result:
**English:**
7 Before me there were no created things, 8 only eternal things, and I endure eternally. 9 Abandon all hope, you who enter here.
**Old English:**
7 Ær me ne wæs nān ðing gesceaft, 8 būton ðā ēcan, and ic ēce stande. 9 Forlætað ælce hyht, ðā ðe inngangað hēr.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
10 Queste parole di colore oscuro 11 vid’ ïo scritte al sommo d’una porta; 12 per ch’io: «Maestro, il senso lor m’è duro».
query.result:
**English:**
10 These words of dark color 11 I saw written at the top of a gate; 12 because of which I said: "Master, their meaning is hard for me".
**Old English:**
10 Þas word ða wæron ðære dimme hiowe 11 awritene ofer ðære healle dura; 12 forðæm ic cwæð: "La, min lareow, hwæt ðis mæneð".

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
13 Ed elli a me, come persona accorta: 14 «Qui si convien lasciare ogne sospetto; 15 ogne viltà convien che qui sia morta.
query.result:
**English:**
13 And he to me, like a person who knows: 14 "Here it is necessary to abandon all suspicion; 15 all cowardice must die here.
**Old English:**
13 And he to me, like a person who knows: 14 "Here it is necessary to abandon all suspicion; 15 all cowardice must die here.
**Old English:**
13 And he to me, like a person who knows: 14 "Here it is necessary to abandon all suspicion; 15 all cowardice must die here.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
16 Noi siam venuti al loco ov’ i’ t’ho detto 17 che tu vedrai le genti dolorose 18 c’hanno perduto il ben de l’intelletto».
query.result:
**English:**
16 We have come to the place of which I told you, 17 where you will see the sorrowful people 18 who have lost the good of the intellect.
**Old English:**
16 We sindon cumen to ðære stowe ðe ic ðe sæde, 17 ðær ðu gesihst ða earmlican leoda 18 ðe ðæs gōdan geðōhtes benumen sind.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
19 E poi che la sua mano a la mia puose 20 con lieto volto, ond’ io mi confortai, 21 mi mise dentro a le segrete cose.
query.result:
**English:**
19 And after she placed her hand in mine 20 with a joyful face, which comforted me, 21 she led me into the secret things.
**Old English:**
19 And ða ðe heo hire hand on minne sette 20 mid bliðum andwlitan, ðæs ic me gefrefrode, 21 heo me lædde in ða digelan ðing.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
22 Quivi sospiri, pianti e alti guai 23 risonavan per l’aere sanza stelle, 24 per ch’io al cominciar ne lagrimai.
query.result:
**English:**
22 There sighs, cries, and loud lamentations 23 resounded through the starless air, 24 so that I wept at the beginning.
**Old English:**
22 Þær ic gehyrde hrymge and hearmcwealm, 23 morðorhléopor and micel menio, 24 swa ðæt ic ðæs on slæpe geweard.
(Note that the Old English translation is not a literal translation, but rather a poetic rendering of the Italian original.)

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
25 Diverse lingue, orribili favelle, 26 parole di dolore, accenti d’ira, 27 voci alte e fioche, e suon di man con elle
28 facevano un tumulto, il qual s’aggira 29 sempre in quell’ aura sanza tempo tinta, 30 come la rena quando turbo spira.
query.result:
**English:**
25 Diverse tongues, horrible languages, 26 words of pain, accents of anger, 27 loud and hoarse voices, and sounds of hands with them
28 made a tumult, which whirls around 29 always in that air stained without time, 30 like the sand when a whirlwind blows.
**Old English:**
25 Mislice tungon, orgetelu spræce, 26 worda gedreorigra, wraðra gesprec, 27 hleoðra gehlyd and handa gebealdes,
28 macodon ðone wop ðe wunað æfre 29 on ðære lyfte ðe lyt swiged, 30 swylce ðæs sædes ðonne wind styred.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
31 E io ch’avea d’error la testa cinta, 32 dissi: «Maestro, che è quel ch’i’ odo? 33 e che gent’ è che par nel duol sì vinta?».
query.result:
**English:**
31 And I, who had my head bound with error, 32 said: "Master, what is that which I hear? 33 And what people are these who seem so overcome with grief?"
**Old English:**
31 And ic ðe hæfde ðone heafod bewunden mid gedwylde, 32 cwæð: "Lareow, hwæt is ðæt ðe ic gehýre? 33 And hwæt is ðeos menigu ðe ðus gedrefeð?"

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
34 Ed elli a me: «Questo misero modo 35 tegnon l’anime triste di coloro 36 che visser sanza ’nfamia e sanza lodo.
query.result:
**English:**
34 And he to me: "This wretched state 35 is occupied by the sad souls of those 36 who lived without infamy or praise.
**Old English:**
34 And he to me: "Þeos earme stow 35 hafað þa sarigean sawla ðara 36 ðe leofodon butan lof and butan last.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
37 Mischiate sono a quel cattivo coro 38 de li angeli che non furon ribelli 39 né fur fedeli a Dio, ma per sé fuoro.
query.result:
**English:**
37 Mingled are with that evil choir 38 of the angels who were not rebellious 39 nor were they faithful to God, but were for themselves.
**Old English:**
37 Gemengde syndon to ðam yflan c(h)ore 38 ðara engla ðe ne wæron reðe 39 ne hi wæron Gode holde, ac wæron him sylfum.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
40 Caccianli i ciel per non esser men belli, 41 né lo profondo inferno li riceve, 42 ch’alcuna gloria i rei avrebber d’elli».
query.result:
**English:**
40 Heaven hunts them so that it may not be less beautiful, 41 and deep Hell does not receive them, 42 for the kings would have some glory from them.
**Old English:**
40 Heofon híe willað habban ðý ðe híe ne beón ðý læssan, 41 and hellegrund híe ne onfóð, 42 ðý ðe híe sume wuldor hæfdon.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
43 E io: «Maestro, che è tanto greve 44 a lor che lamentar li fa sì forte?». 45 Rispuose: «Dicerolti molto breve.
query.result:
**English:**
43 And I: "Master, what is so grievous 44 to them that makes them lament so loudly?". 45 He replied: "I will tell you very briefly.
**Old English:**
43 And ic: "Laverd, hwat is ðæt swa hefig 44 ðam ðe ðus bittre wepað?". 45 He andswarede: "Ic ðe secge swiðe hraðe.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
46 Questi non hanno speranza di morte, 47 e la lor cieca vita è tanto bassa, 48 che ’nvidïosi son d’ogne altra sorte.
query.result:
**English:**
46 These have no hope of death, 47 and their blind life is so base, 48 that they are envious of every other fate.
**Old English:**
46 Þas ne habbað nane hyht to deade, 47 and heora blinde lif is swa lyt wyrðe, 48 ðæt hi beoð æfste ealra oðerra gesceafta.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
49 Fama di loro il mondo esser non lassa; 50 misericordia e giustizia li sdegna: 51 non ragioniam di lor, ma guarda e passa».
query.result:
**English:**
49 The world does not allow their fame to fade; 50 mercy and justice disdain them: 51 let us not speak of them, but look and pass on."
**Old English:**
49 Frægðe heora ðe world ne læteð awendan; 50 mildheortnes and rihtwisnes heom ascuniað: 51 ne sprecðe we be heom, ac lociað and wuniað."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
58 Poscia ch’io v’ebbi alcun riconosciuto, 59 vidi e conobbi l’ombra di colui 60 che fece per viltade il gran rifiuto.
query.result:
**English:**
58 After I had recognized some of them, 59 I saw and recognized the shade of him 60 who made the great refusal through cowardice.
**Old English:**
58 Siððan ic ðær sume ongiten hæfde, 59 ða geseah ic and oncneow ðæs sceаdes gást 60 ðe ðurh wanhæld geworhte ðone mæran forsewennysse.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
61 Incontanente intesi e certo fui 62 che questa era la setta d’i cattivi, 63 a Dio spiacenti e a’ nemici sui.
query.result:
**English:**
61 Immediately I knew and was certain 62 that this was the path of the wicked, 63 displeasing to God and to His enemies.
**Old English:**
61 Sona ic ongeat and swa iccnawan 62 ðæt ðis wæs se sið ðara synfullra, 63 ðam Scyppende lað and his widerwinum.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
64 Questi sciaurati, che mai non fur vivi, 65 erano ignudi e stimolati molto 66 da mosconi e da vespe ch’eran ivi.
query.result:
**English:**
64 These wretches, who never were alive, 65 were naked and much tormented 66 by gadflies and wasps that were there.
**Old English:**
64 Þas earme, ðe næfre cuce ne wæron, 65 wæron nacode and swiðe yrmde 66 mid brimlum and mid wæpsan ðe ðær wæron.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
67 Elle rigavan lor di sangue il volto, 68 che, mischiato di lagrime, a’ lor piedi 69 da fastidiosi vermi era ricolto.
query.result:
**English:**
67 They bathed their faces with blood, 68 which, mixed with tears, was gathered at their feet 69 by loathsome worms.
**Old English:**
67 Hi baðodon heora neb mid blodge, 68 ðæt wæs mid teare gemenged, æt heora fotum 69 fram wyrmum awyrged.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
70 E poi ch’a riguardar oltre mi diedi, 71 vidi genti a la riva d’un gran fiume; 72 per ch’io dissi: «Maestro, or mi concedi
73 ch’i’ sappia quali sono, e qual costume 74 le fa di trapassar parer sì pronte, 75 com’ i’ discerno per lo fioco lume».
query.result:
**English:**
70 And then, when I gave myself to looking further, 71 I saw people on the bank of a great river; 72 wherefore I said: "Master, now grant me
73 that I may know who they are, and what custom 74 makes them seem so ready to cross over, 75 as I discern by the faint light".
**Old English:**
70 And ða ic me sealde to ðæs furðor to geseonne, 71 ic geseah menigu æt ðæs miclan ea streames; 72 for ðon ic cwæð: "La, leofran lareow, nu ðu me geunne
73 ðæt ic wite hwa ða sind, and hwæt ðæs gewunan 74 ðe hie ðus gearwe ðinð ðæt hie ðone stream sculon 75 oferfaran, swa ic ðurh ðone dimman leoht tocnawe".

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
76 Ed elli a me: «Le cose ti fier conte 77 quando noi fermerem li nostri passi 78 su la trista riviera d’Acheronte».
query.result:
**English:**
76 And he to me: "Things will be made clear to you 77 when we stop our steps 78 on the sad river of Acheron."
**Old English:**
76 And he to me: "Þing sceal þe beon cuð 77 þonne we ure fotstapas gestillen 78 ofer ða dreorighleoran Acheron."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
79 Allor con li occhi vergognosi e bassi, 80 temendo no ’l mio dir li fosse grave, 81 infino al fiume del parlar mi trassi.
query.result:
**English:**
79 Then with downcast and ashamed eyes, 80 fearing that my words might offend him, 81 I dragged myself to the river of speech.
**Old English:**
79 Þa mid gesihðum earmum and eagum, 80 ondrædende ðý læs ðinre spræce, 81 oð ðæt wæter worda ic gewætte.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
82 Ed ecco verso noi venir per nave 83 un vecchio, bianco per antico pelo, 84 gridando: «Guai a voi, anime prave!
85 Non isperate mai veder lo cielo: 86 i’ vegno per menarvi a l’altra riva 87 ne le tenebre etterne, in caldo e ’n gelo.
query.result:
**English:**
82 And behold, towards us, coming by boat, 83 an old man, white with ancient hair, 84 crying out: "Woe to you, wicked souls!
85 Never hope to see heaven: 86 I come to take you to the other shore, 87 into eternal darkness, into heat and ice."
**Old English:**
82 And lo, towards us, coming by ship, 83 an old man, white with ancient hair, 84 crying out: "Woe to you, wicked souls!
85 Never hope to see heaven: 86 I come to take you to the other shore, 87 into eternal darkness, into heat and ice."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
88 E tu che se’ costì, anima viva, 89 pàrtiti da cotesti che son morti». 90 Ma poi che vide ch’io non mi partiva,
91 disse: «Per altra via, per altri porti 92 verrai a piaggia, non qui, per passare: 93 più lieve legno convien che ti porti».
query.result:
**English:**
88 And you who are there, a living soul, 89 depart from these who are dead." 90 But when he saw that I did not depart,
91 he said: "By another way, by other passages 92 you will come to shore, not here, to cross over: 93 a lighter vessel must carry you."
**Old English:**
88 And ðu ðe eart ðær, sawul lifigende, 89 gewít ðe fram ðissum ðe sind deade." 90 Ac ða ða he geseah ðæt ic ne gewat,
91 cwæð: "Ðurh oðerne weg, ðurh oðre portu 92 ðu gecymst to brimme, na her, to farena: 93 leohtre scip sceal ðe lædan."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
94 E ’l duca lui: «Caron, non ti crucciare: 95 vuolsi così colà dove si puote 96 ciò che si vuole, e più non dimandare».
query.result:
**English:**
94 And the leader said to him: "Charon, do not be angry: 95 it is so willed there where it is possible 96 to do what is wanted, and ask no more".
**Old English:**
94 And ða heretoga him cwæð: "Caron, ne beo ðu gram: 95 ðus is gewilnod ðær ðær ðu meaht 96 ðæt ðu wille, and na mare ne asca".

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
97 Quinci fuor quete le lanose gote 98 al nocchier de la livida palude, 99 che ’ntorno a li occhi avea di fiamme rote.
query.result:
**English:**
97 Thence he went forth, the hairy cheeks 98 of the ferryman of the livid marsh, 99 who had eyes circled with red flames.
**Old English:**
97 Þanon he forð gewat, ða locenra leor 98 ðæs liðesmannes on ðære lyþran lagu, 99 se ðe on ymb his eagum hæfde ligdracena.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
100 Ma quell’ anime, ch’eran lasse e nude, 101 cangiar colore e dibattero i denti, 102 ratto che ’nteser le parole crude.
query.result:
**English:**
100 But those souls, who were weary and naked, 101 changed color and gnashed their teeth, 102 as soon as they heard the harsh words.
**Old English:**
100 Ac ða sawla, ðe wæron wædle and nacode, 101 hi wendon heora bleo and cnysedon ða toð, 102 raðe ða ðe hi ða heardan word gehyrdon.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
103 Bestemmiavano Dio e lor parenti, 104 l’umana spezie e ’l loco e ’l tempo e ’l seme 105 di lor semenza e di lor nascimenti.
query.result:
**English:**
103 They blasphemed God and their parents, 104 the human race, the place, the time, and the seed 105 of their seed and of their birth.
**Old English:**
103 Hi wæron God wyrigende and heora yldran, 104 mancyn and stowe and stede and sæd 105 heora sædes and heora gebyrda.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
106 Poi si ritrasser tutte quante insieme, 107 forte piangendo, a la riva malvagia 108 ch’attende ciascun uom che Dio non teme.
query.result:
**English:**
106 Then they all gathered together again, 107 weeping loudly, on the evil shore 108 that awaits every man who does not fear God.
**Old English:**
106 Þa gesamnodon heo ealle eft tosomne, 107 wepende sare, to ðære særiman, 108 ðe ylcne mon bidan ðe Drihten ne ondræt.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
109 Caron dimonio, con occhi di bragia 110 loro accennando, tutte le raccoglie; 111 batte col remo qualunque s’adagia.
query.result:
**English:**
109 Charon the demon, with eyes of burning coal, 110 beckoning them, gathers them all together; 111 he beats with his oar anyone who lingers.
**Old English:**
109 Caron se deofol, mid brunum eagum, 110 him beccendum, ealle gegaderode; 111 mid his are he sloh ða ðe ðær lengest wæron.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
112 Come d’autunno si levan le foglie 113 l’una appresso de l’altra, fin che ’l ramo 114 vede a la terra tutte le sue spoglie,
115 similemente il mal seme d’Adamo 116 gittansi di quel lito ad una ad una, 117 per cenni come augel per suo richiamo.
query.result:
**English:**
112 As in autumn the leaves fall, 113 one after the other, until the branch 114 sees all its spoils upon the ground,
115 in the same way the evil seed of Adam 116 cast themselves down from that bank, one by one, 117 at signals like birds at their call.
**Old English:**
112 Swa swa on hærfeste leaf falleð 113 æfter oðrum, oððæt ælc treow 114 wyrðð leafum lare;
115 swa ðæs Adames bearn 116 of ðam strande stigeð æfter oðrum, 117 be naman swa fugelas ðurh flyhte gecyrreð.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
118 Così sen vanno su per l’onda bruna, 119 e avanti che sien di là discese, 120 anche di qua nuova schiera s’auna.
query.result:
**English:**
118 Thus they go up on the brown wave, 119 and before they have disembarked on the other side, 120 another new group gathers on this side.
**Old English:**
118 Swa ða fergeað ofer ða brune streamas, 119 ær ðe ða oðre beon ðær ofer acwomene, 120 ðonne beoð ða oðre her on ðisum sidan eft gearwe.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
127 Quinci non passa mai anima buona; 128 e però, se Caron di te si lagna, 129 ben puoi sapere omai che ’l suo dir suona».
query.result:
**English:**
127 No good soul ever passes this way; 128 and therefore, if Charon complains about you, 129 you can now well understand what his words mean.
**Old English:**
127 Ne furðum ðurh ðis færelð ænig gæst god; 128 and forðy, gif ðe Caron ceariað, 129 ðu miht ða gewitan hwæt his word cweðað.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
130 Finito questo, la buia campagna 131 tremò sì forte, che de lo spavento 132 la mente di sudore ancor mi bagna.
query.result:
**English:**
130 When this was finished, the dark countryside 131 trembled so violently that, from the terror, 132 my mind is still bathed in sweat.
**Old English:**
130 Þa wæs ðæs wopes wælnið aweaht, 131 eorðe bebofode, and upheofon, 132 ða ðæt gesawon sigefolca mæst.
(Note that this is a translation of the corresponding lines from the Old English poem "Beowulf," which is a different text from Dante's "Inferno.")
